elements.content: The solvothermal cycloreversion and in situ oxidation of 1,2,3,4-tetra­(pyridin-4-yl)­cyclobutane (tpcb) within [CuCN] n -based MOFs were investigated. The radical mechanism for the cycloreversion of tpcb ligands was supported by capturing a 1,3-butadiene species 1,2,3,4-tetra­(4-pyridyl)-1,3-butadiene (tpyb) into {[Cu18­(μ-CN)18­(tpcb)4­(tpyb)2]·H2O} n in the presence of 2,2,6,6-tetra­methyl­piperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO). Without TEMPO, a furan-based ligand 2,3,4,5-tetra­(4-pyridyl)­furan (tpyf) was generated within {[Cu4­(μ-CN)4­(tpyf)]·4MeCN} n via the C–C cleavage, followed by in situ oxidation in acidic condition.
elements.clean_text: The solvothermal cycloreversion and in situ oxidation of 1,2,3,4-tetra(pyridin-4-yl)cyclobutane (tpcb) within [CuCN] n -based MOFs were investigated. The radical mechanism for the cycloreversion of tpcb ligands was supported by capturing a 1,3-butadiene species 1,2,3,4-tetra(4-pyridyl)-1,3-butadiene (tpyb) into {[Cu18(μ-CN)18(tpcb)4(tpyb)2]⋅H2O} n  in the presence of 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO). Without TEMPO, a furan-based ligand 2,3,4,5-tetra(4-pyridyl)furan (tpyf) was generated within {[Cu4(μ-CN)4(tpyf)]⋅4MeCN} n  via the C-C cleavage, followed by in situ oxidation in acidic condition.

elements.content: Solvothermal cycloreversion of 1,2,3,4-tetra­(pyridin-4-yl)­cyclobutane (tpcb) in the presence of 2,2,6,6-tetra­methyl­piperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) affords an uncommon 1,3-butadiene species, 1,2,3,4-tetra­(4-pyridyl)-1,3-butadiene (tpyb), which is captured by [CuCN] n units to form a three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer {[Cu18­(μ-CN)18­(tpcb)4­(tpyb)2]·H2O} n . However, if no TEMPO exists, a furan-based ligand 2,3,4,5-tetra­(4-pyridyl)­furan (tpyf) is solvothermally generated within the other 3D coordination polymer {[Cu4­(μ-CN)4­(tpyf)]·4MeCN} n via the C−C cleavage, followed by in situ oxidation in acidic condition. Both results support that the cycloreversion of the tpcb ligand may undergo a radical mechanism.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal cycloreversion of 1,2,3,4-tetra(pyridin-4-yl)cyclobutane (tpcb) in the presence of 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) affords an uncommon 1,3-butadiene species, 1,2,3,4-tetra(4-pyridyl)-1,3-butadiene (tpyb), which is captured by [CuCN] n  units to form a three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer {[Cu18(μ-CN)18(tpcb)4(tpyb)2]⋅H2O} n . However, if no TEMPO exists, a furan-based ligand 2,3,4,5-tetra(4-pyridyl)furan (tpyf) is solvothermally generated within the other 3D coordination polymer {[Cu4(μ-CN)4(tpyf)]⋅4MeCN} n  via the C-C cleavage, followed by in situ oxidation in acidic condition. Both results support that the cycloreversion of the tpcb ligand may undergo a radical mechanism.

elements.content: The selective carbon–carbon (C–C) single bond activation is an important hotspot in academic and industrial laboratories. In spite of the thermodynamic stability of the C–C bonds, there has been a growing interest in their catalytic activation and transformation. The past decades have witnessed a significant progress in activating the C–C bonds of strained three- and four-membered rings. Cyclobutanes are essential structural motifs for numerous unique organic transformations. The catalytic C–C bond activation of the functionalized cyclobutane derivatives including cyclobutanols, cyclobutanones, cyclobutendiones, benzocyclobutanes, and benzocyclobutenols can offer unique routes to the construction of new organic molecules. To date, the cycloreversion of tetra­arylcyclobutanes has rarely been documented. The [2 + 2] photodimerization of olefins and the cycloreversion of the resulting cyclobutane species via UV/microwave irradiation or UV/heating have been reported and might be applicable in switching devices and rewritable optical data storage. However, the mechanism of the cyclobutane cycloreversion has remained arguable. Although many techniques like in situ NMR, mass spectroscopy, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) could be available for the mechanism investigation, it is still a tough job to acquire important information about the in situ formed intermediates, which are key to understanding the mechanism of organic reactions. Recently, metal–organic-frameworks (MOFs) have become one type of powerful structural materials which can be used as straightforward alternative tools for performing some organic reactions and capturing the in situ cleaved species within their frameworks. We also reported that the hydrothermal reaction of CdCl2 with 1,3-benzene­dicarbox­ylic acid (1,3-H2bdc), 1,3-bis­(4′-pyridyl)­2,4-bis­(phenyl)­cyclobutane (HT-ppcb), and H2O2 afforded one unique 2D MOF, {[Cd­(H2O)­(1,3-bdc)­(bpbpf)]·H2O} n (bpbpf = 2,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)-3,5-bis­(phenyl)­furan). In this reaction, HT-ppcb was converted into bpbpf via the ring-opening of HT-ppcb, followed by in situ oxidation, which was trapped into this MOF. We tentatively proposed a radical mechanism for the formation of bpbpf, but had no more further proofs to clarify it. On the other hand, reactions of CuX (X = halide or pseudohalide) with various organic ligands can yield various [Cu m X n ]-based MOFs. Some of these MOFs could be used to catch the intermediate species derived from the cleavage of C–X (X = C, S, N) bonds within their own frameworks. Thus, in this work, we employ an analogue of HT-ppcb, 1,2,3,4-tetra­(pyridin-4-yl)­cyclobutane (tpcb), to react with CuCN under solvothermal conditions. Through fine-tuning the reaction conditions, the resulting [CuCN] n -based MOFs did capture one 1,3-butadiene product and one funan-based product, generated by cycloreversion of the tpcb ligands, which is described below.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The selective carbon-carbon (C-C) single bond activation is an important hotspot in academic and industrial laboratories. In spite of the thermodynamic stability of the C-C bonds, there has been a growing interest in their catalytic activation and transformation. The past decades have witnessed a significant progress in activating the C-C bonds of strained three- and four-membered rings. Cyclobutanes are essential structural motifs for numerous unique organic transformations. The catalytic C-C bond activation of the functionalized cyclobutane derivatives including cyclobutanols, cyclobutanones, cyclobutendiones, benzocyclobutanes, and benzocyclobutenols can offer unique routes to the construction of new organic molecules. To date, the cycloreversion of tetraarylcyclobutanes has rarely been documented. The [2 + 2] photodimerization of olefins and the cycloreversion of the resulting cyclobutane species via UV/microwave irradiation or UV/heating have been reported and might be applicable in switching devices and rewritable optical data storage. However, the mechanism of the cyclobutane cycloreversion has remained arguable. Although many techniques like in situ NMR, mass spectroscopy, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) could be available for the mechanism investigation, it is still a tough job to acquire important information about the in situ formed intermediates, which are key to understanding the mechanism of organic reactions. Recently, metal-organic-frameworks (MOFs) have become one type of powerful structural materials which can be used as straightforward alternative tools for performing some organic reactions and capturing the in situ cleaved species within their frameworks. We also reported that the hydrothermal reaction of CdCl2 with 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2bdc), 1,3-bis(4'-pyridyl)2,4-bis(phenyl)cyclobutane (HT-ppcb), and H2O2 afforded one unique 2D MOF, {[Cd(H2O)(1,3-bdc)(bpbpf)]⋅H2O} n  (bpbpf = 2,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-3,5-bis(phenyl)furan). In this reaction, HT-ppcb was converted into bpbpf via the ring-opening of HT-ppcb, followed by in situ oxidation, which was trapped into this MOF. We tentatively proposed a radical mechanism for the formation of bpbpf, but had no more further proofs to clarify it. On the other hand, reactions of CuX (X = halide or pseudohalide) with various organic ligands can yield various [Cu m X n ]-based MOFs. Some of these MOFs could be used to catch the intermediate species derived from the cleavage of C-X (X = C, S, N) bonds within their own frameworks. Thus, in this work, we employ an analogue of HT-ppcb, 1,2,3,4-tetra(pyridin-4-yl)cyclobutane (tpcb), to react with CuCN under solvothermal conditions. Through fine-tuning the reaction conditions, the resulting [CuCN] n -based MOFs did capture one 1,3-butadiene product and one funan-based product, generated by cycloreversion of the tpcb ligands, which is described below.

elements.content:
The ligand tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane (tpcb) was synthesized as reported before. The analytic instruments engaged in this work are the same as those used in our previous works.

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>7</sub>(μ-CN)<sub>7</sub>(tpcb)<sub>2</sub>]<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of tpcb (3.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), H2O (0.5 mL), and MeCN (1.0 mL) was sealed into a glass tube, which was heated to 160 °C for 36 h. After smoothly cooling to room temperature (5 °C h–1), light-yellow crystals for 1 were harvested, washed with MeOH, and dried in air at room temperature. Yield: 3.0 mg (44% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C55H40­Cu7N15: C, 48.67; H, 2.95; N, 15.48. Found: C, 49.07; H, 3.02; N, 14.97. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3449­(m), 2122(s), 2106(s), 1680­(m), 1613(s), 1498­(w), 1421(s), 1384­(m), 1301(s), 1223­(m), 1132­(w), 1068­(m), 1010­(m), 845­(m), 832(s), 819(s), 654­(w), 619­(m), 545(s), 508­(w).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

The ligand tetrakis(4-pyridyl)cyclobutane (tpcb) was synthesized as reported before. The analytic instruments engaged in this work are the same as those used in our previous works. 

Synthesis of [Cu7(μ-CN)7(tpcb)2] n  (1)

A mixture of tpcb (3.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), H2O (0.5 mL), and MeCN (1.0 mL) was sealed into a glass tube, which was heated to 160 °C for 36 h. After smoothly cooling to room temperature (5 °C h-1), light-yellow crystals for 1 were harvested, washed with MeOH, and dried in air at room temperature. Yield: 3.0 mg (44% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C55H40Cu7N15: C, 48.67; H, 2.95; N, 15.48. Found: C, 49.07; H, 3.02; N, 14.97. IR (KBr disk, cm-1): 3449(m), 2122(s), 2106(s), 1680(m), 1613(s), 1498(w), 1421(s), 1384(m), 1301(s), 1223(m), 1132(w), 1068(m), 1010(m), 845(m), 832(s), 819(s), 654(w), 619(m), 545(s), 508(w).

elements.content: To a glass tube was placed with a mixture of CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), tpcb (36 mg, 0.01 mmol), MeCN (1.0 mL), and HCl (0.1 M, 0.5 mL). Then this tube was bubbled with oxygen for 30 min. A similar workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded light-red crystals of 2. Yield: 2.0 mg (28% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C32H28­Cu4N12O: C, 42.72; H, 3.11; N, 18.70. Found: C, 42.77; H, 3.31; N, 18.58. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3438­(m), 3055­(w), 2129(s), 1604(s), 1501­(w), 1501­(w), 1484­(w), 1416­(m), 1384­(m), 1216­(m), 1174­(w), 1067­(m), 1013­(m), 959­(w), 852­(m), 828(s), 775­(w), 740­(w), 713­(m), 680­(m), 653­(m), 537­(w), 510­(w).

To a glass tube was placed with a mixture of CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), tpcb (36 mg, 0.01 mmol), MeCN (1.0 mL), and HCl (0.1 M, 0.5 mL). Then this tube was bubbled with oxygen for 30 min. A similar workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded light-red crystals of 2. Yield: 2.0 mg (28% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C32H28Cu4N12O: C, 42.72; H, 3.11; N, 18.70. Found: C, 42.77; H, 3.31; N, 18.58. An analogous workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded red crystals of 3. Yield: 1.3 mg (21% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C162H116­Cu18N42: C, 51.01; H, 3.04; N, 15.42. Found: C, 51.23; H, 3.15; N, 15.89. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3440­(m), 2113(s), 1607(s), 1496­(w), 1419­(m), 1384­(w), 1222­(w), 1068­(m), 904­(w), 842­(w), 834­(m), 819­(m), 593­(w), 544­(m), 506­(w).

Synthesis of [Cu18(μ-CN)18(tpcb)4(tpyb)2⋅H2O] n  (3)

A mixture of CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), tpcb (3.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), MeCN (1.0 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), TEMPO (3.0 mg, 0.02 mmol), and HCl (0.1 M, 0.2 mL) were placed in a glass tube. An analogous workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded red crystals of 3. Yield: 1.3 mg (21% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C162H116Cu18N42: C, 51.01; H, 3.04; N, 15.42. Found: C, 51.23; H, 3.15; N, 15.89. IR (KBr disk, cm-1): 3440(m), 2113(s), 1607(s), 1496(w), 1419(m), 1384(w), 1222(w), 1068(m), 904(w), 842(w), 834(m), 819(m), 593(w), 544(m), 506(w).

elements.content: Single crystals of 1–3 suitable for X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were mounted with Fomblin in a cryoloop. The measurements of 1–3 were performed on a Bruker APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 120 K. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the SHELXTL-2014 program. In 1, it was difficult to locate and refine all the solvent molecule peaks, because the guest solvent molecules were highly disordered. The SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suite was used to eliminate the electron density contributions from the disordered solvent molecules, and the generated data were used for further refinement of the structure. For 2, the calculated solvent accessible void volume per unit cell estimated by PLATON after removing the disordered MeCN solvent in 2 was 796.2 Å3. Since disorder models did not give satisfactory results, the solvent contribution to the scattering factors was taken into account with PLATON/​SQUEEZE. A total of 88 electrons were found in a unit cell, corresponding to approximately four MeCN molecules per chemical formula. For 1–3, the C/N atoms of partial μ-cyanides were indistinguishable. Thus, each of the atomic sites was set to have an occupancy of 50% C and 50% N. The H2O molecule in 3 was refined to 50% occupancy to give acceptable thermal parameters. In 3, full matrix least-squares refinements were performed on F 2 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms, except for the O atom of the H2O molecule. The pertinent crystal data for 1–3 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1–S3.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of 1-3 suitable for X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were mounted with Fomblin in a cryoloop. The measurements of 1-3 were performed on a Bruker APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 120 K. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the SHELXTL-2014 program. In 1, it was difficult to locate and refine all the solvent molecule peaks, because the guest solvent molecules were highly disordered. The SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suite was used to eliminate the electron density contributions from the disordered solvent molecules, and the generated data were used for further refinement of the structure. For 2, the calculated solvent accessible void volume per unit cell estimated by PLATON after removing the disordered MeCN solvent in 2 was 796.2 Å3. Since disorder models did not give satisfactory results, the solvent contribution to the scattering factors was taken into account with PLATON/SQUEEZE. A total of 88 electrons were found in a unit cell, corresponding to approximately four MeCN molecules per chemical formula. For 1-3, the C/N atoms of partial μ-cyanides were indistinguishable. Thus, each of the atomic sites was set to have an occupancy of 50% C and 50% N. The H2O molecule in 3 was refined to 50% occupancy to give acceptable thermal parameters. In 3, full matrix least-squares refinements were performed on F 2 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms, except for the O atom of the H2O molecule. The pertinent crystal data for 1-3 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1-S3.

Crystal Data and Structure Refinement Parameters for <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold> 1 2 3 empirical formula C55H40Cu7N15 C32H28Cu4N12O C162H118Cu18N42O fw 1355.87 898.69 3812.70 cryst syst monoclinic monoclinic monoclinic space group P2/c P21/n P2/c a (Å) 21.0066(11) 17.7984(12) 26.1853(16) b (Å) 8.4961(5) 8.2415(6) 8.5074(5) c (Å) 18.4306(10) 22.6619(16) 18.2483(10) α (deg) β (deg) 114.018(2) 102.415(2) 93.601(2) γ (deg) V (Å3) 3004.6(3) 3246.4(4) 4057.1(4) ρcalc (g/cm–3) 1.499 1.503 1.560 Z 2 4 1 μ (mm–1) 2.477 2.617 2.367 F(000) 1356.0 1456.0 1912.0 R 1 0.0597(4635) 0.0304(4821) 0.0833(5381) wR 2 0.1419(6889) 0.1042(6024) 0.2402(9253) GOF 1.006 0.952 1.036

R 1= ∑||F o| – |F c||/∑|F o|.

wR 2= {∑w(F o 2 – F c 2)2/∑w(F o 2)2}1/2.

GOF = {∑w((F o 2 – F c 2)2)/(n – p)}1/2, where n = number of reflections and p = total number of parameters refined.

Solvothermal reaction of CuCN with tpcb ligand in a 2:1 molar ratio in a mixed solvent of MeCN and H2O (v/v = 2:1) at 160 °C for 36 h generated the light yellow crystals of 1 with the formula [Cu7­(μ-CN)7­(tpcb)2] n (1) in ca. 40% yield. When similar reaction was investigated at lower temperature (140 °C), 1 was isolated in a lower yield (ca. 15%). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1 matched quite well with that simulated from its single crystal data (Figure S1a). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that 1 is stable until 230 °C (Figure S2a). An X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and its asymmetric unit holds half of a [Cu7­(μ-CN)7­(tpcb)2] molecule. Cu1 adopts a tetrahedral coordination mode to bind at two N atoms from two tpcb ligands and two μ-CN– anions (a). Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4 have a trigonal planar geometry, coordinated by one pyridyl ring of tpcb and two μ-CN– anions. The Cu1–N­(pyridyl) bond distance (2.147(5) Å) (Table S1) is consistent with those found in {[Cu­(CN)­(bpzb)]} n (bpzb = bis­(pyrazole-1-yl)­alkane) (2.145–2.166 Å). The three-coordinated Cu–N­(pyridyl) lengths (2.075(5)–​2.097(6) Å) are longer than those found in [Cu2(L)­(CN)2] n (L = 4,4′-bis­(5,6-dimethyl­benz­imidazol-1-yl­methyl)­biphenyl) (1.996(5) Å). The Cu···Cu contacts vary from 4.897(8) to 4.947(10) Å, which exclude any metal-to-metal interactions. In 1, the four pyridyl rings of each tpcb hold an up-down-up-down conformation, and the dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings are 89.13° and 68.65°, respectively (Figure S3). In 1, the adjacent Cu­(I) atoms bind at two μ-CN– to form a 1D zigzag chain along the c axis (Figure S4). These chains are interconnected by tpcb ligands with the four terminal pyridyl rings to afford one 3D framework (b). The effective size of this rhombic window for each channel is ca. 13 × 6 Å2 by measuring the diagonal centers. While considering tpcb ligands and Cu atoms as 3- or 4-connecting nodes, the framework of 1 can be regarded as a 3D net with a (6,72,­82,9)2­(6,82)2­(62,72,­82)­(7,82)2­(72,8)2 Schläfli symbol (Figure S5a). Such two 3D nets are further interpenetrated into each other to form a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure S5b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization of 1 

Solvothermal reaction of CuCN with tpcb ligand in a 2:1 molar ratio in a mixed solvent of MeCN and H2O (v/v = 2:1) at 160 °C for 36 h generated the light yellow crystals of 1 with the formula [Cu7(μ-CN)7(tpcb)2] n  (1) in ca. 40% yield. When similar reaction was investigated at lower temperature (140 °C), 1 was isolated in a lower yield (ca. 15%). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1 matched quite well with that simulated from its single crystal data (Figure S1a). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that 1 is stable until 230 °C (Figure S2a). An X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and its asymmetric unit holds half of a [Cu7(μ-CN)7(tpcb)2] molecule. Cu1 adopts a tetrahedral coordination mode to bind at two N atoms from two tpcb ligands and two μ-CN- anions (a). Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4 have a trigonal planar geometry, coordinated by one pyridyl ring of tpcb and two μ-CN- anions. The Cu1-N(pyridyl) bond distance (2.147(5) Å) (Table S1) is consistent with those found in {[Cu(CN)(bpzb)]} n  (bpzb = bis(pyrazole-1-yl)alkane) (2.145-2.166 Å). The three-coordinated Cu-N(pyridyl) lengths (2.075(5)-2.097(6) Å) are longer than those found in [Cu2(L)(CN)2] n  (L = 4,4'-bis(5,6-dimethylbenzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl) (1.996(5) Å). The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu contacts vary from 4.897(8) to 4.947(10) Å, which exclude any metal-to-metal interactions. In 1, the four pyridyl rings of each tpcb hold an up-down-up-down conformation, and the dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings are 89.13° and 68.65°, respectively (Figure S3). In 1, the adjacent Cu(I) atoms bind at two μ-CN- to form a 1D zigzag chain along the c axis (Figure S4). These chains are interconnected by tpcb ligands with the four terminal pyridyl rings to afford one 3D framework (b). The effective size of this rhombic window for each channel is ca. 13 × 6 Å2 by measuring the diagonal centers. While considering tpcb ligands and Cu atoms as 3- or 4-connecting nodes, the framework of 1 can be regarded as a 3D net with a (6,72,82,9)2(6,82)2(62,72,82)(7,82)2(72,8)2 Schläfli symbol (Figure S5a). Such two 3D nets are further interpenetrated into each other to form a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure S5b).

elements.content: (a) View of the coordination surroundings of Cu­(I) centers in 1 with a labeling scheme. (b) 3D framework of 1 viewed down the b axis. Cu, N, and C atoms are shown in blue, cyan, and gray spheres, respectively. All H atoms were omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the coordination surroundings of Cu(I) centers in 1 with a labeling scheme. (b) 3D framework of 1 viewed down the b axis. Cu, N, and C atoms are shown in blue, cyan, and gray spheres, respectively. All H atoms were omitted for clarity.

elements.content: When the MeCN/H2O mixture of CuCN and tpcb was acidified by dilute HCl to pH = 2–3 in open air, the yield of 1 could be increased up to 90%. However, the bulk crystals of 1 were coupled with several orange blocks of {[Cu4­(μ-CN)4­(tpyf)]·4MeCN} n (2, tpyf = 2,3,4,5-tetra­(4-pyridyl)­furan), which were mechanically separated under a microscope. Single-crystal X-ray analysis confirms that 2 belongs to the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit has one [Cu4­(μ-CN)4­(tpyf)] molecule and four MeCN molecules. In 2, each Cu­(I) is coordinated by one N atom from one tpyf and two μ-CN– anions (a), forming a trigonal planar coordination geometry. The mean Cu–N­(pyridyl) bond distance of 2.08(2) Å is similar to the corresponding one in 1 (Table S2). In 2, the four pyridyl rings of each tpcb hold an up-down-up-down conformation, and the dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings are 71.11° and 47.03°, respectively (Figure S6). Each tpyf ligand in 2 works as a tetradentate bridge to bind at four Cu­(I) atoms. The adjacent Cu­(I) atoms are further linked by μ-CN– anions to form a 1D spiral chain along the b axis (Figure S7). These 1D chains are interconnected by tpyf bridges to form one 3D net with 1D channels of an approximate window size of 10 × 9 Å2 (b). If each Cu­(I) and each tpyf are viewed as 3-connecting and 4-connecting nodes, respectively, the structure of 2 can be viewed as a (3,4)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of (4,5,­7,8,92)­(4,5,7)­(5,8,9)­(52,83,9) (Figure S8a). Then two equivalent nets are interpenetrated to form a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework (Figure S8b).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Structural Characterization of 2 

When the MeCN/H2O mixture of CuCN and tpcb was acidified by dilute HCl to pH = 2-3 in open air, the yield of 1 could be increased up to 90%. However, the bulk crystals of 1 were coupled with several orange blocks of {[Cu4(μ-CN)4(tpyf)]⋅4MeCN} n  (2, tpyf = 2,3,4,5-tetra(4-pyridyl)furan), which were mechanically separated under a microscope. Single-crystal X-ray analysis confirms that 2 belongs to the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit has one [Cu4(μ-CN)4(tpyf)] molecule and four MeCN molecules. In 2, each Cu(I) is coordinated by one N atom from one tpyf and two μ-CN- anions (a), forming a trigonal planar coordination geometry. The mean Cu-N(pyridyl) bond distance of 2.08(2) Å is similar to the corresponding one in 1 (Table S2). In 2, the four pyridyl rings of each tpcb hold an up-down-up-down conformation, and the dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings are 71.11° and 47.03°, respectively (Figure S6). Each tpyf ligand in 2 works as a tetradentate bridge to bind at four Cu(I) atoms. The adjacent Cu(I) atoms are further linked by μ-CN- anions to form a 1D spiral chain along the b axis (Figure S7). These 1D chains are interconnected by tpyf bridges to form one 3D net with 1D channels of an approximate window size of 10 × 9 Å2 (b). If each Cu(I) and each tpyf are viewed as 3-connecting and 4-connecting nodes, respectively, the structure of 2 can be viewed as a (3,4)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of (4,5,7,8,92)(4,5,7)(5,8,9)(52,83,9) (Figure S8a). Then two equivalent nets are interpenetrated to form a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework (Figure S8b).

elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environments of Cu­(I) centers in 2 with a labeling system. (b) 3D framework of 2 looking down the b axis. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. See Figure for color codes, and the red spheres represent O atoms.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View of the coordination environments of Cu(I) centers in 2 with a labeling system. (b) 3D framework of 2 looking down the b axis. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. See Figure   for color codes, and the red spheres represent O atoms.

elements.content: According to the above structure analysis of 2, a small amount of tpcb was found to be converted into the previously unknown furan-based tpyf ligand during the solvothermal reaction. In this transformation, the cyclobutane ring of tpcb underwent only one C–C bond cleavage, which was different from the cleavage of the cyclobutane ring into two olefins. Where did the O atom of tpyf in 2 originate from? Under the N2 atmosphere, the similar reaction of the same components could not afford 2. Compound 1 was the only product isolated in a crystalline form regardless of the CuCN/​tpcb/​H2O molar ratios. Thus, a water molecule as the O source for tpyf was ruled out. However, when we bubbled O2 into the mixture of CuCN and tpcb in MeCN/H2O solution for 30 min, the yield of 2 was significantly raised up to 30%. This result suggested that O2 in air did work for this conversion. No tpyf was isolated when analogous reactions were carried out at pH < 2 or > 4. Without the addition of CuCN, the solvothermal reaction of tpcb under the same conditions failed to yield any tpyf. These results indicated that O2, H+, and CuCN exerted an important impact on the formation of tpyf. Thus, we proposed one radical mechanism for the formation of tpyf (). First, tpcb underwent the thermal cleavage of one C–C bond into the radical species (I). The radical (I) was then captured by O2 to form the dioxane intermediate (II), which could be subsequently converted into tpyf in the presence of H+ ion. In order to further verify the presence of reaction intermediates, we introduced 2,2,6,6-tetra­methyl­piperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) as a radical scavenger into the reaction. To our surprise, solvothermal reactions of CuCN with tpcb and TEMPO in a 2:1:2 ratio in MeCN/H2O at 160 °C did not yield any coordination complexes bearing the radical species (I) (). Instead, another 3D MOF {[Cu18­(μ-CN)18­(tpcb)4­(tpyb)2]·H2O} n (3, tpyb = 1,2,3,4-tetra­(4-pyridyl)-1,3-butadiene) was isolated in 20% yield along with a small amount of 1. In this reaction, TEMPO abstracts H• from the intermediate I to generate tpyb and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-ol (TEMPOH). The latter was decomposed into 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine, which was verified by mass spectrum (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text:
Formation of Tpyf and Tpyb

According to the above structure analysis of 2, a small amount of tpcb was found to be converted into the previously unknown furan-based tpyf ligand during the solvothermal reaction. In this transformation, the cyclobutane ring of tpcb underwent only one C-C bond cleavage, which was different from the cleavage of the cyclobutane ring into two olefins. Where did the O atom of tpyf in 2 originate from? Under the N2 atmosphere, the similar reaction of the same components could not afford 2. Compound 1 was the only product isolated in a crystalline form regardless of the CuCN/tpcb/H2O molar ratios. Thus, a water molecule as the O source for tpyf was ruled out. However, when we bubbled O2 into the mixture of CuCN and tpcb in MeCN/H2O solution for 30 min, the yield of 2 was significantly raised up to 30%. This result suggested that O2 in air did work for this conversion. No tpyf was isolated when analogous reactions were carried out at pH < 2 or > 4. Without the addition of CuCN, the solvothermal reaction of tpcb under the same conditions failed to yield any tpyf. These results indicated that O2, H+, and CuCN exerted an important impact on the formation of tpyf. Thus, we proposed one radical mechanism for the formation of tpyf (). First, tpcb underwent the thermal cleavage of one C-C bond into the radical species (I). The radical (I) was then captured by O2 to form the dioxane intermediate (II), which could be subsequently converted into tpyf in the presence of H+ ion. In order to further verify the presence of reaction intermediates, we introduced 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) as a radical scavenger into the reaction. To our surprise, solvothermal reactions of CuCN with tpcb and TEMPO in a 2:1:2 ratio in MeCN/H2O at 160 °C did not yield any coordination complexes bearing the radical species (I) (). Instead, another 3D MOF {[Cu18(μ-CN)18(tpcb)4(tpyb)2]⋅H2O} n  (3, tpyb = 1,2,3,4-tetra(4-pyridyl)-1,3-butadiene) was isolated in 20% yield along with a small amount of 1. In this reaction, TEMPO abstracts H⋅ from the intermediate I to generate tpyb and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-ol (TEMPOH). The latter was decomposed into 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine, which was verified by mass spectrum (Figure S9).

elements.clean_text: 1  A Possible Pathway from tpcb to tpyf or tpyb

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 2/c, and its asymmetric unit contains a quarter of one [Cu18­(μ-CN)18­(tpcb)4­(tpyb)2] molecule and a quarter of one water molecule. The Cu­(I) atoms in 3 show three different coordination geometries (a). Cu1 and Cu3 adopt a tetrahedral geometry to bind at two N atoms from one tpcb, one tpyb ligand, and two μ-CN– anions. Cu2 is linearly coordinated by two μ-CN– anions. Cu4 and Cu5 are three-coordinated by one pyridyl group from tpcb and two μ-CN– anions. The tetrahedral Cu1–​N­(pyridyl) and Cu3–​N­(pyridyl) distances are in the range of 2.105(7)–​2.151(7) Å (Table S3), which are similar to the corresponding ones in 1. The three-coordinated Cu–N­(pyridyl) lengths of 2.065(4)–​2.083(6) Å) are comparable with those in 2. The two-coordinated Cu2–​N­(pyridyl) distance (1.814(7) Å) is shorter than those observed in [Cu7­(CN)7­(apt)2] n (apt = amino­pyridyl-1,2,4-triazole) (1.850(6) Å). In 3, the four pyridyl rings of each tpcb also take an up-down-up-down conformation (Figure S10a) and the dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings (84.30° and 63.69°) are smaller than those of the corresponding ones in 1. Notably, each tpyb ligand shows an unprecedented 1,3-butadiene conformation in which the two CC bonds (1.347(1) Å) are not located in the same plane but get twisted with a dihedral angle between two CC bonds (57.38(6)°) (Figure S10b). The four pyridyl rings of each tpyb are also not sitting in the same plane, and their dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings are 56.15° and 74.64°. These unusual distortion features of the tpyb ligand may be due to the rigid framework of 3. The μ-CN– anions link adjacent Cu­(I) atoms to construct a 1D zigzag chain running along the [101] direction. (Figure S11). The tpcb and tpyb ligands act as 4-connecting nodes to connect Cu–​CN–​Cu–​CN chains in the different directions to form one 3D net (b). If Cu2, Cu4/Cu5, Cu1/Cu3 are considered as 2-, 3-, and 4-connecting nodes and tpcb or tpyb is viewed as a 4-connecting node, 3 can be symbolized as a (2, 3, 4)-connected topological structure with a Schläfli symbol of (6,7,­82,102)2­(6,7,84)2­(62,84)­(7,82)2­(72,83,9)2­(72,8)2­(8) (Figure S12). The water molecules occupy the 1D channels with approximate window dimensions of 13 × 10 Å2. The above elucidation of the structure of 3 suggested that tpcb might undergo the CuCN-catalyzed cycloreversion reaction to form the radical species (I) (), which was successively oxidized by TEMPO into the tpyb ligand. The in situ formed tpyf and tpyb ligands were captured by different in situ-generated [CuCN] n motifs, producing the corresponding MOFs 2 and 3. We have changed the molar ratios of CuCN/​tpcb/​TEMPO from 1:1:1 to 1:1:5 or reaction temp­eratures and found that tpcb was still partially converted into tpyb ligand and the yield of this conversion was the highest when the molar ratio was fixed at 1:1:2 at 160 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 3 

Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 2/c, and its asymmetric unit contains a quarter of one [Cu18(μ-CN)18(tpcb)4(tpyb)2] molecule and a quarter of one water molecule. The Cu(I) atoms in 3 show three different coordination geometries (a). Cu1 and Cu3 adopt a tetrahedral geometry to bind at two N atoms from one tpcb, one tpyb ligand, and two μ-CN- anions. Cu2 is linearly coordinated by two μ-CN- anions. Cu4 and Cu5 are three-coordinated by one pyridyl group from tpcb and two μ-CN- anions. The tetrahedral Cu1-N(pyridyl) and Cu3-N(pyridyl) distances are in the range of 2.105(7)-2.151(7) Å (Table S3), which are similar to the corresponding ones in 1. The three-coordinated Cu-N(pyridyl) lengths of 2.065(4)-2.083(6) Å) are comparable with those in 2. The two-coordinated Cu2-N(pyridyl) distance (1.814(7) Å) is shorter than those observed in [Cu7(CN)7(apt)2] n  (apt = aminopyridyl-1,2,4-triazole) (1.850(6) Å). In 3, the four pyridyl rings of each tpcb also take an up-down-up-down conformation (Figure S10a) and the dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings (84.30° and 63.69°) are smaller than those of the corresponding ones in 1. Notably, each tpyb ligand shows an unprecedented 1,3-butadiene conformation in which the two CC bonds (1.347(1) Å) are not located in the same plane but get twisted with a dihedral angle between two CC bonds (57.38(6)°) (Figure S10b). The four pyridyl rings of each tpyb are also not sitting in the same plane, and their dihedral angles between the two opposite pyridyl rings are 56.15° and 74.64°. These unusual distortion features of the tpyb ligand may be due to the rigid framework of 3. The μ-CN- anions link adjacent Cu(I) atoms to construct a 1D zigzag chain running along the [101] direction. (Figure S11). The tpcb and tpyb ligands act as 4-connecting nodes to connect Cu-CN-Cu-CN chains in the different directions to form one 3D net (b). If Cu2, Cu4/Cu5, Cu1/Cu3 are considered as 2-, 3-, and 4-connecting nodes and tpcb or tpyb is viewed as a 4-connecting node, 3 can be symbolized as a (2, 3, 4)-connected topological structure with a Schläfli symbol of (6,7,82,102)2(6,7,84)2(62,84)(7,82)2(72,83,9)2(72,8)2(8) (Figure S12). The water molecules occupy the 1D channels with approximate window dimensions of 13 × 10 Å2. The above elucidation of the structure of 3 suggested that tpcb might undergo the CuCN-catalyzed cycloreversion reaction to form the radical species (I) (), which was successively oxidized by TEMPO into the tpyb ligand. The in situ formed tpyf and tpyb ligands were captured by different in situ-generated [CuCN] n  motifs, producing the corresponding MOFs 2 and 3. We have changed the molar ratios of CuCN/tpcb/TEMPO from 1:1:1 to 1:1:5 or reaction temperatures and found that tpcb was still partially converted into tpyb ligand and the yield of this conversion was the highest when the molar ratio was fixed at 1:1:2 at 160 °C.

elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environments of Cu­(I) centers in 3 with a labeling scheme. (b) 3D framework of 3 viewed down the b axis. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. See Figure for color codes.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) View of the coordination environments of Cu(I) centers in 3 with a labeling scheme. (b) 3D framework of 3 viewed down the b axis. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. See Figure   for color codes.

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated an interesting approach in which MOFs are used to harness the species derived from the solvothermal cycloreversion of the cyclobutane derivative tpcb, and the elucidation of their structures may get more insight into the mechanism of such a conversion. The cycloreversion of the tpcb ligand might follow a copper­(I)-mediated radical mechanism (). The radical intermediate species might undergo different types of reconstruction in the presence or absence of the radical scavenger TEMPO, yielding the 1,3-butadiene product tpyb and the furan-based product tpyf, which are further enclosed and stabilized by the frameworks of MOFs 2 and 3, respectively. It is anticipated that the methodology using suitable [Cu m X n ]-supported MOFs to trap the cleaved species and regain some delicate mechanism information could be applied to other relevant C–Y (Y = C, N, O, P, S, Si) cleavage systems under solvothermal conditions. Studies about this respect are ongoing in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have demonstrated an interesting approach in which MOFs are used to harness the species derived from the solvothermal cycloreversion of the cyclobutane derivative tpcb, and the elucidation of their structures may get more insight into the mechanism of such a conversion. The cycloreversion of the tpcb ligand might follow a copper(I)-mediated radical mechanism (). The radical intermediate species might undergo different types of reconstruction in the presence or absence of the radical scavenger TEMPO, yielding the 1,3-butadiene product tpyb and the furan-based product tpyf, which are further enclosed and stabilized by the frameworks of MOFs 2 and 3, respectively. It is anticipated that the methodology using suitable [Cu m X n ]-supported MOFs to trap the cleaved species and regain some delicate mechanism information could be applied to other relevant C-Y (Y = C, N, O, P, S, Si) cleavage systems under solvothermal conditions. Studies about this respect are ongoing in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
The ligand tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane (tpcb) was synthesized as reported before. The analytic instruments engaged in this work are the same as those used in our previous works.

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>7</sub>(μ-CN)<sub>7</sub>(tpcb)<sub>2</sub>]<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of tpcb (3.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), H2O (0.5 mL), and MeCN (1.0 mL) was sealed into a glass tube, which was heated to 160 °C for 36 h. After smoothly cooling to room temperature (5 °C h–1), light-yellow crystals for 1 were harvested, washed with MeOH, and dried in air at room temperature. Yield: 3.0 mg (44% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C55H40­Cu7N15: C, 48.67; H, 2.95; N, 15.48. Found: C, 49.07; H, 3.02; N, 14.97. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3449­(m), 2122(s), 2106(s), 1680­(m), 1613(s), 1498­(w), 1421(s), 1384­(m), 1301(s), 1223­(m), 1132­(w), 1068­(m), 1010­(m), 845­(m), 832(s), 819(s), 654­(w), 619­(m), 545(s), 508­(w).

Synthesis of {[Cu<sub>4</sub>(μ-CN)<sub>4</sub>(tpyf)]·4MeCN}<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>2</bold>)

To a glass tube was placed with a mixture of CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), tpcb (36 mg, 0.01 mmol), MeCN (1.0 mL), and HCl (0.1 M, 0.5 mL). Then this tube was bubbled with oxygen for 30 min. A similar workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded light-red crystals of 2. Yield: 2.0 mg (28% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C32H28­Cu4N12O: C, 42.72; H, 3.11; N, 18.70. Found: C, 42.77; H, 3.31; N, 18.58. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3438­(m), 3055­(w), 2129(s), 1604(s), 1501­(w), 1501­(w), 1484­(w), 1416­(m), 1384­(m), 1216­(m), 1174­(w), 1067­(m), 1013­(m), 959­(w), 852­(m), 828(s), 775­(w), 740­(w), 713­(m), 680­(m), 653­(m), 537­(w), 510­(w).

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>18</sub>(μ-CN)<sub>18</sub>(tpcb)<sub>4</sub>(tpyb)<sub>2</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), tpcb (3.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), MeCN (1.0 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), TEMPO (3.0 mg, 0.02 mmol), and HCl (0.1 M, 0.2 mL) were placed in a glass tube. An analogous workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded red crystals of 3. Yield: 1.3 mg (21% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C162H116­Cu18N42: C, 51.01; H, 3.04; N, 15.42. Found: C, 51.23; H, 3.15; N, 15.89. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3440­(m), 2113(s), 1607(s), 1496­(w), 1419­(m), 1384­(w), 1222­(w), 1068­(m), 904­(w), 842­(w), 834­(m), 819­(m), 593­(w), 544­(m), 506­(w).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

The ligand tetrakis(4-pyridyl)cyclobutane (tpcb) was synthesized as reported before. The analytic instruments engaged in this work are the same as those used in our previous works. 

Synthesis of [Cu7(μ-CN)7(tpcb)2] n  (1)

A mixture of tpcb (3.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), H2O (0.5 mL), and MeCN (1.0 mL) was sealed into a glass tube, which was heated to 160 °C for 36 h. After smoothly cooling to room temperature (5 °C h-1), light-yellow crystals for 1 were harvested, washed with MeOH, and dried in air at room temperature. Yield: 3.0 mg (44% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C55H40Cu7N15: C, 48.67; H, 2.95; N, 15.48. Found: C, 49.07; H, 3.02; N, 14.97. IR (KBr disk, cm-1): 3449(m), 2122(s), 2106(s), 1680(m), 1613(s), 1498(w), 1421(s), 1384(m), 1301(s), 1223(m), 1132(w), 1068(m), 1010(m), 845(m), 832(s), 819(s), 654(w), 619(m), 545(s), 508(w).

Synthesis of {[Cu4(μ-CN)4(tpyf)]⋅4MeCN} n  (2)

To a glass tube was placed with a mixture of CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), tpcb (36 mg, 0.01 mmol), MeCN (1.0 mL), and HCl (0.1 M, 0.5 mL). Then this tube was bubbled with oxygen for 30 min. A similar workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded light-red crystals of 2. Yield: 2.0 mg (28% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C32H28Cu4N12O: C, 42.72; H, 3.11; N, 18.70. Found: C, 42.77; H, 3.31; N, 18.58. IR (KBr disk, cm-1): 3438(m), 3055(w), 2129(s), 1604(s), 1501(w), 1501(w), 1484(w), 1416(m), 1384(m), 1216(m), 1174(w), 1067(m), 1013(m), 959(w), 852(m), 828(s), 775(w), 740(w), 713(m), 680(m), 653(m), 537(w), 510(w).

Synthesis of [Cu18(μ-CN)18(tpcb)4(tpyb)2⋅H2O] n  (3)

A mixture of CuCN (0.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), tpcb (3.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), MeCN (1.0 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), TEMPO (3.0 mg, 0.02 mmol), and HCl (0.1 M, 0.2 mL) were placed in a glass tube. An analogous workup to that used for the formation of 1 afforded red crystals of 3. Yield: 1.3 mg (21% based on tpcb). Anal. Calcd for C162H116Cu18N42: C, 51.01; H, 3.04; N, 15.42. Found: C, 51.23; H, 3.15; N, 15.89. IR (KBr disk, cm-1): 3440(m), 2113(s), 1607(s), 1496(w), 1419(m), 1384(w), 1222(w), 1068(m), 904(w), 842(w), 834(m), 819(m), 593(w), 544(m), 506(w).

R 1= ∑||F o| – |F c||/∑|F o|.

wR 2= {∑w(F o 2 – F c 2)2/∑w(F o 2)2}1/2.

GOF = {∑w((F o 2 – F c 2)2)/(n – p)}1/2, where n = number of reflections and p = total number of parameters refined.

(a) View of the coordination surroundings of Cu­(I) centers in 1 with a labeling scheme. (b) 3D framework of 1 viewed down the b axis. Cu, N, and C atoms are shown in blue, cyan, and gray spheres, respectively. All H atoms were omitted for clarity.
